titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the William P. Hobby, Jr. and Diana Poteat Hobby Family Collection, ca. 1950s-2000s MS 628

publicationstmt.publisher: Woodson Research Center, Rice University, Houston, Texas

note.p: Stored off-site at the Library Service Center. Please request this material via woodson@rice.edu or call 713-348-2586.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-07-15 10:23:51 -0500.

did.head: Collection Summary

repository.corpname: Woodson Research Center, Rice University, Houston, Texas

did.unittitle: William P. Hobby Jr. & Diana Poteat Hobby Family Collection
did.abstract: The collection includes Diana P. Hobby's writing and research notes, from the early 1950s to 2014, focused on her study of William Butler Yeats. The bulk of the collection consists of family photographs and slides from the Hobby family's worldwide travels and their frequent visits to Ireland, and to Diana Hobby's family farm in North Carolina, Forest Home, along with their equestiran endeavors and competitions, and their lives and friends in Houston, TX.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Diana Poteat Stallings Hobby (1931-2014), the daughter of writer Laurence T. Stallings and his wife, Helen Poteat, was born in New York City. She graduated from Radcliffe College in 1952 and received her Ph.D. at Rice University in 1981. She was book editor of the Houston Post, a longtime editor of Studies in English Literature at Rice, and a lifelong champion of the humanities, libraries, and nature conservancy.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: William Pettus Hobby, Jr. (1931- ), born in Houston and a 1953 Rice University graduate, was lieutenant governor of Texas, 1973-1991. He is the namesake son of a former Texas governor and of Oveta Culp Hobby, director of the Women's Army Corps and first secretary of Health, Education, and Welfare. William P. Hobby, Sr., and his wife were publishers of the Houston Post, of which their son was president, 1963-1983. He was chancellor of the University of Houston system, 1995-1997, and taught at the University of Texas at at Rice. Married in 1954, the Hobbys had four children: Laura Hobby Beckworth, Paul W. Hobby, Andrew P. Hobby, and Katherine Hobby Gibson.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection includes Diana P. Hobby's writing and research notes, from the early 1950s to 2014, focused on her study of William Butler Yeats. The bulk of the collection consists of family photographs and slides from the Hobby family's worldwide travels and their frequent visits to Ireland, and to Diana Hobby's family farm in North Carolina, Forest Home, along with their equestiran endeavors and competitions, and their lives and friends in Houston, TX.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Stored off-site at the Library Service Center. Please request this material via woodson@rice.edu or call 713-348-2586.

arrangement.head: Arrangement

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Permission to publish from the William P. Hobby, Jr. and Diana Poteat Hobby Family Collection must be obtained from the Woodson Research Center, Fondren Library.

did.unittitle: Series I: Papers of Diana P. Hobby and William P. Hobby, Jr.
Typescript, senior thesis of D.P. Hobby, Radcliffe College, "The Praise of Life: A Study of the Dramatic Work of William Butler Yeats as it is Represented by Four Plays"
James P. O'Reilly to Brinsley Macnamara [John Weldon] letters, transcriptions, including transcriptions of Yeats materials, 1919-1922
Yeats 1922 correspondence, transcriptions, with notes by Hobby
Hobby correspondence about Yeats and Edmund Dulac letters
Typescript of Hobby dissertation on Yeats and Dulac
Hobby citations about Lady Augusta Gregory
Hobby notes on Yeats papers at Harry Ransom Center, University of Texas
Hobby notes on Yeats from vaious published sources
D.P. Hobby, "William Butler Yeats and Edmund Dulac: A Correspondence, 1916-1938, " Ph.D. dissertation (bound), Rice University
Publicity about various publications on Yeats
Harry Ransom Center Advisory Council minutes and correspondence, including Henri Pierre Roche exhibition proposal
William W. Lowe to William P. Hobby, with vacation photos
Series II: Photographs of family at Forest Home, Caswell County, NC
Portraits of African-Americans, most from NC
W.P. Hobby in India with Prime Minister Nehru and US Pres. Eisenhower
Andrew F. Muir (1959), Hobby children (1970), Ann & Charles Duncah, Nancy & George Rupp, Peggy Barnett, D.P. & W. P. Hobby in NM (Sept.1992)
D.P. & W.P. Hobby, Jessica Catto, Hobby children
D.P. & W.P. Hobby, fox hunt, Ireland
Series IV: Photographs: family, friends, vacations
Hobby's North Blvd. house with horses and carriages
Friends, including Caitlin Finn, Duncan Shumate, Glenn Burt, Gertrude Barnstone, Marguerite Johnston Barnes
Scotland, including Paul Hobby, Louie Welch, Bob Eckels
Ireland; includes Renee & Frank E. Vandiver
Colorado, Montana, Syria, Spain, including Kay Bailey & Ray Hutchison
New Mexico, including Anne & Charles Duncan, Nancy & George Rupp, Peggy & Bill Barnett
U.K., Friends of Fondren [Rice Univ.] library tour
W.P. & D.P. Hobby campaigning; Hobby family
Hobby family at Forest Home; including LBJ
D.P. & W.P. Hobby, Rice campus, Studies in English Literature office in Fondren Library
